topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the podcast and Annie Pearl’s background (CPO at Calendly, former CPO at Glassdoor, prior roles), plus a quick preview of what they’ll cover in the episode.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Miro and Coda, including how they’re used for collaboration and product team operations.

topics.title: How to share Calendly without awkwardness
topics.summary: Annie shares practical etiquette tips: invite the other person to share availability first, then optionally include a Calendly link and even paste suggested times to reduce friction.

topics.title: Breaking into product management from nontraditional roles
topics.summary: Annie outlines multiple entry paths into PM: APM programs, applying for junior PM roles (often internally), shadowing/partnering with PMs, SME programs, and joining early-stage startups to take on PM work.

topics.title: Which PM transition paths work best
topics.summary: They discuss which routes are most common and effective, with Annie emphasizing internal transfers via demonstrated interest, curiosity, and doing real product work before holding the title.

topics.title: Why APM programs are rare and hard
topics.summary: Annie explains the operational overhead of building APM programs (interviewing, training, role expectations, graduation paths) and why many companies lack the scale/capacity to do them well.

topics.title: Calendly product org scale and structure
topics.summary: Annie shares Calendly’s growth (150→600 employees; product/design/research ~15→~60) and how leadership is organized across core, enterprise, and platform, with design/research/product ops under product leadership.

topics.title: Team structure by persona: core, enterprise, platform
topics.summary: They break down how teams map to personas and problems: core experience + PLG funnel, enterprise admins and department leaders, and platform integrations/APIs to embed Calendly into workflows.

topics.title: OKRs maturity: from siloed to integrated planning
topics.summary: Annie describes Calendly’s evolution from unclear strategy/no OKRs to product OKRs, then to tightly linked company OKRs with dependency mapping and cross-functional execution.

topics.title: Narrowing ICP to improve prioritization and focus
topics.summary: Annie explains how clarifying target markets and personas (sales, recruiting, customer success) reduced prioritization thrash and enabled stronger product decisions, despite cultural resistance to saying no.

topics.title: Calendly’s viral growth loop and PLG-to-SLG shift
topics.summary: They discuss Calendly’s growth engine (70% signups via viral loop) and how adding a sales-led motion changed hiring profiles, buyer personas, and cross-functional operating model.

topics.title: Product and sales collaboration: using GTM as customer lens
topics.summary: Annie argues sales/GTM can be a product team’s biggest asset for customer empathy, sharing lessons from Box about spending time in the field and leveraging sales’ customer exposure.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Vanta focused on SOC 2 compliance automation and why it matters for selling to enterprise customers.

topics.title: Prioritization via strategy and horizons allocation
topics.summary: Annie shares a strategy framework (Playing to Win) and how Calendly allocates resources across three horizons over multiple years; she gives an example of deprioritizing a Venmo integration due to ICP focus.

topics.title: Planning cadence, roadmaps, and delivery commitments
topics.summary: They cover annual company OKRs with quarterly milestones, roadmaps tied to KRs, and a phased product development lifecycle (discovery, solutioning, build, launch/iterate) to avoid overcommitting too early.

topics.title: Strategy artifacts and product team tool stack
topics.summary: Annie describes how strategy is documented (3-year strategy, OKR docs → slides, Confluence templates) and the team’s tools (Aha, Airtable, Jira, Slack, Loom, Pendo, Google Docs/Slides).

topics.title: Origin story: getting Calendly’s first users
topics.summary: Annie begins recounting how founder Tope Awotona bootstrapped Calendly (401k savings, outsourced dev firm) and how the first users came through connections to that development firm; the story continues beyond the provided excerpt.
